job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Baltimore, MD
pros: I have been an employee at Mercy for over 16years ( but I actually started my nursing career @ Mercy 21 years ago and being a new nurse I wanted to explore that was the only reason why I left) and I think its a great place to work. Great environment, knowledgeable physicians and nurses. I believe everyone works to the best of our ability to give exceptional patient care ( so much so I choose to get my care at Mercy).
cons: No place is perfect but I believe we all work together to achieve the best results. I don't have a con, I honestly believe this is a great hospital.

pros: Supportive management Employee perks Benefits
cons: Promotional opportunities are inequitable across departments

pros: opportunity for growth, mostly supportive environment, yearly raises
cons: some favoritism, sometimes encoraged to do more with less

pros: Remote, flex schedule, good benefits
cons: Raises are below average and slow

pros: Excellent work atmosphere with management that truly cares about your experiences an employer. Regular incentivizing events are held to motivate staff. I’ve worked for 12 years and it’s the best job I’ve ever worked
cons: Not too much to complain about other than paying for parking (not a bad rate but when others are remote it can be frustrating) and having to pay a fee per paycheck to include your spouse on health coverage. (If they have access to coverage elsewhere ONLY)

cons: The department is unorganized, littered with nepotism, favoritism, and unprofessionalism . You can only grow/get promoted if you know someone in leadership role within your already department. They don't promote by merit. Hired a handful of minorities out of panic to avoid possible lawsuit.

pros:
Camaraderie. Good relationships with coworkers.
Everyone is friendly for the most part. Ok pay
cons: Management. Lack of upper management support, but only due to lack of knowledge about the real issues.

review_title: Poor work-life balance, often toxic work culture
pros: They have high unit standards on SOME units, good patient care on SOME units, and overall friendly staff. Their base salary is slightly higher than the local hospitals, due to their smaller reputation and their refusal to accept outside agency travel nurses. Health insurance and benefits are fine, mostly on par with local hospitals.
cons: Chronic short-staffing, endless restrictions on taking time off, penalization for being sick or making small mistakes, obsessive work culture, high nurse turnover, staff taking advantage of each other, very frequent floating to other units (without additional compensation to make up for this), and offensive $1/hr annual raises to try to 'boost morale'.

pros: There is good insurance, and great management.
cons: There isn't enough money for the amount of work.

review_title: Admin assistant to a very high volume orthopedic surgeon
pros: Co workers, benefits, better pay then SOME area hospitals, security, stability, great doctors at mercy to see if needed. Cafeteria offers great food and good selection
cons: High volume high stress, mercy no longer provides tuition reimbursement for RN programs (must be BSN), very small raises and not very often (Within 4 years make a total of .75 cents more and that's with great reviews) have to pay for parking, no paid maternity leave, horrible dental coverage.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Bel Air, MD
pros: Pays well with decent benefits
cons: Off sites lack proper governance

pros: Nice people for the most part. Newer facilities, fairly secure as far as layoffs go. I also noticed that the CEO listed below is incorrect, Mercy's CEO is Thomas Mullen.
cons: Poor senior management.  My senior manager was clearly unqualified for the position.  In a 5 year period salaried employees got a meager 1 percent raise, yet they are always asking for you to donate to their various construction projects, and raising the cost of your benefits. No incentive to be a high performance employee, as everyone gets the same raise no matter how they perform. You are also expected to put vacations on hold during any big projects.   Many departments are grossly understaffed (as are most health care employers these days) which means be prepared to work a lot of unpaid OT.  They do nothing to retain the best talent.

review_title: Low pay, raises are few and far between
pros: Nice people,  nice building to work in
cons: Raises are very rare, benefits are limited.  Physicians are not held to same standards as employees. Some are great, but there are a few who act unprofessionally, and HR turns a blind eye to situations where a normal employee would be reprimanded or terminated.

review_title: Hard work deserves recognition and monetary rewards.
pros: Your co workers start out great and caring because most are actually  good people.
cons: The work load is excessive due to constant call outs.  NST's are constantly pulled as sitters.   Charge nurses have to take the same about of patients as the regular RN's. There is a huge turnover. The  average nurse has 2 years or less experience.  NO merit reviews.   You can excel but are not given any incentive  for being an excellent .  Only the RN's  & DR 's  seem to be appreciated,  not the support staff.  The work load is unevenly distributed.  Management is over whelmed.

pros: it is a stepping stone.  You step in and step out.  As soon as you get hired, start updating your resume.
cons: Mercy is very  diverse but does not treat its employees the same.  It is not racially friendly.  Yes, you will get hired but you will not be promoted and your salary will stay the same. Even though, they bring other people in the department who will make more than you and do less.

pros: Easy job for anyone with a college degree, very redundant reports, could easily finish work in the first few hours of the day.
cons: Upper management is a joke. They are secretive, rude, and unsupportive. Really not a lot to learn once you master your position. People are constantly quitting. Micromanagement is awful- you literally cannot send an email unless it is approved by 3 people first.

review_title: The best place to work for new RN's
pros: Great start for a new grad! Teaching hospital! Lots of resources. I started off as a CNA and Im now a Nurse Practitioner. They baby their young and then you blossom into an awesome practitioner.
cons: Scheduling ? Yuck you have to put in your vacation time way in advance!

review_title: Excellent, sorry I left the organization.
pros: Employee recognition, organization commitment to mission, pleasant work conditions, good benefits.  Reasonable parking support, forward thinking administration, interesting colleagues.  A lot of people can say that they were born at Mercy and now work there, it's true!
cons: Sometimes can be inflexible on scheduling but keep in mind, it is a health care setting.  Too much staff division according to class.  Organization needs to pay more attention to institutional issues around class divisions.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Baltimore, MD
pros: No weekends, on the job training, paid Epic training, good benefits
cons: Paying for parking, no room for growth in specific office, horrible management, didn't get an exit interview from HR

pros: It's great to have your doctors here, to really see great medical advances firsthand
cons: Very inflexible in inclement weather, even for nonessential staff. Ridiculous medical changes even when you're an employee, on their insurance, at their facility. Limited advancement potential since HR picks and chooses who to forward to hiring managers.

pros: Very few, good PTO that is about it!  Had a good boss and there are a lot of good people to work with.
cons: Most of Senior Leadership!  There has been some great people pushed out the past year and a half, either by their own decision or forced.  Performance excellence department is a joke!  They don't do anything but create headaches for most Managers!  Spirit rallies are annoying, as is the dancing by Senior Leaders before spirit rallies!  Any how I am very happy to be gone from there!!!

review_title: I like the patient care. Transporting patients you get to know them very well.
pros:
Benefits with full time 
Free food sometimes 
Meeting a lot of people
Must have communication skills 
Comfortable clothes (scrubs) 
Get to work holidays which is time and half
cons:
ALOT of walking 
Very tiring 
I get home and want to take a nap
Have to constantly wash your hands
You get sick easily if your prone to germs

review_title: I worked there for 7 plus years and was treated very UNFAIRLY and dismissed because the operations manager disliked me.
pros: I did not have to see the management if I worked the night shifts. All the drama was not there.
cons: Unfair treatment - HR does not even try to help or disfuse any situations - the managers of the department can do as they wish - take it or leave it.  No reason to have any job loyalty.  Kangaroo court by HR with Managers.  A horror story.

pros: Health benefits, simple work.
cons: The work culture, is not always the greatest.

pros: Good position out of college. May have the ability to move up if you are well liked.
